Came here for a late brunch with family on a lovely Sunday summer afternoon. I had heard a lot about Sarabeth's and had seen locations - as far as Osaka. The beginnings were largely a negative. The crab meat guacamole & chips was tasteless: all three parts. The crab meat was devoid of any crab flavor, the guacamole was like eating into mushy nothing, and the chips was like "crunching" into wobbly flavorless cardboard disks. The dainty muffins and sweet jams were tasty, admittedly, but not something I'd go out-of-my-way for. I went for the short rib hash with poblano peppers. It wasn't any mind-blowing but a bit of a deviation from the conventional. The peppers provided a bit of a different flavor to a regular hash. The short rib itself was decent, as it was fairly tender and flavorful. The over-medium eggs on top were perfectly cooked and that I can appreciate. Service was very polite and thoughtful. The only blemish was that I did not get my berry-corn muffin until I brought it up to a server. Otherwise, I appreciated the good service. On a side note, unless you decide to try the handicapped restrooms, the regular restrooms are a bit of a hike (going flights of stairs) from the dining area. The more premium price is for the atmosphere and name; not necessarily the food. 3.5 stars, but I'll raise it a tad because the wait staff.

Sarabeth's is great! I've gone to the location in Central Park (extremely long wait) & this one for the 4th of July. My mom was born on 4th of July, so it was her birthday. We celebrated it with a party of 14. They set up tables in the backroom, in a quiet area which I liked a lot. It was more private compared to the front of the house. The server was OKAY, I wasn't too fond of him because he wasn't engaged at all with the guests and I; it seemed as if he was bothered and they also brought out the food to the wrong people 3 times. The food on the other hand, was delicious once again! My whole table ordered almost everything off the brunch menu (which was served on the 4th of July even though it's only served on the weekends.) I ordered the jalapeño, cheese & cilantro omelette with a croissant. It was delicious and flavorful! One thing I absolutely loved which I tried from my family members was the fluffy french toast (it was indeed fluffy!) & the egg & cream cheese popover!! OMG, the popover was so fluffy & delicious, I could not stop picking off of my uncle's plate. It was the most softest egg with the combination of the hard/soft bread. Wow, I was amazed at how good that tasted. Overall, this location was nice and had the same great tasting food!
Overpriced for the quality of food served.  Glad I tried Sarabeth's but there are definitely better brunch places in town.
Great Breakfast! Love the place. Staff was very attentive & nice. Ricotta pancakes & Bacon were so yummy.

As far as brunch/breakfast places, this place isn't really that great to be honest. Huge space with lots of great light and it wasn't busy at all when we arrived for breakfast at 8:30.Had the eggs benedict and was just so so so underwhelmed. Everything about it was just meh. They serve it with a weird salad that isn't really even a salad but more like a lumping of various greens on a plate. No thanks. Honestly this was my least favorite meal i had in NYC.They also don't even poach their eggs but use one of those weird little molds to make them all uniform. My eggs weren't really runny and the amount of hollandaise sauce was seriously lacking. Mimosa was decent though.

I came here with a large group for lunch. Overall, the meal was fine, but nothing special. My appetizer house greens salad was average in terms of quality and taste, which could also be said of the cookies that ended the meal. As for my entree, the lobster roll, I was similarly satisfied, but not necessarily inspired. It was mediocre for a lobster roll, though they did get the flavors right and the serving size was reasonable. Overall, the meal was good, but nothing more.

My husband and I got married at Sarabeth's - yes, you read that correctly. Greta and her team made our day perfect, and were incredible to work with throughout the entire planning process. I'm sure that Greta was a little skeptical when she first received our "group brunch inquiry," but she is truly a master event planner who has thought of everything... even if Sarabeth's had never hosted a wedding before. The staff executed our ceremony and reception with precision, converting a 60-person ceremony space into a 60-person dining space - while all 60 people were inside of it - in about 20 minutes. It was beyond impressive. We chose to bring in a cake, and somewhere along the way, it got squished (unbeknownst to us). I later found out that the Sarabeth's team frantically went out to get a very elegant replacement cake for us on their own dime, even though they were not responsible. It underscored the level of quality service that they deliver. Our guests raved about the food and drinks at our wedding. I think some of them might have eaten entire platters of the lobster rolls. The bartenders were very accommodating, and thought nothing of several 20-somethings drinking multiple rounds of shots at 2 in the afternoon (um, myself included). Sarabeth's is legendary in New York for a reason. Yes, it is a busy restaurant for brunch, but the food is very consistent and the decor is impressive. I know if you're reading this, you're probably not going to get married there... but nonetheless, go there for a special occasion, with a big group of friends, or just for weekend brunch. You'll have a great time.PS We didn't have it at the wedding, but Sarabeth's tomato soup is what dreams are made of. Just FYI.

We ordered pancakes, French toasts and farmer's omelette with croissant and chicken sausage... wonderful presentation. Farmer's omelette and pancakes were amazing but French toasts were of average taste. Not too busy, excellent location and very good environment, a very over priced.. not worth visiting in comparison with the price.

The only redeeming quality about this place is the outdoor space. Maybe Sarabeth's was something awesome back in the day but isn't anymore. The staff was friendly but slow and forgetful. The food was subpar. We ordered guacamole and it came with potato chips. It was weird. Whatever I had, maybe the tomato soup - gave me a very quick and adverse reaction which resulted in ordering an Uber and rushing home to my toilet for a couple hours. One friend ordered a salad that was drowned in oil. She asked for a replacement and never got it. Overall, come for drinks on a nice day on the patio, maybe... but eat anywhere else. I would never eat here again.
Had such a great lunch -- Cosme was an exceptional waiter and gave fantastic service -- can't wait for return for the roasted chicken salad

I ordered french toast (passable). The server asked, "would you like hash browns or home fries?", to which I said home fries. I didn't eat them as they were too savory for breakfast, but I came there for the french toast, not the side dish, right?Wrong. They charged me $8 for the home fries. I would like my $8 back; I already gave you back your home fries.Don't expect a great deal or a great meal.

Really beautiful place with lots of room. Great for big parties especially since there's a big room in the back. The portion sizes were okay but I definitely don't think it's worth the price for breakfast. My fiancé got the short rib hash and that was absolutely amazing but the other brunch options were mediocre. I will say, I've gotten the avocado and burrata toast appetizer before and that was really delicious. I would definitely want to try the lunch/happy hour/dinner here. They have a bunch of happy hour options for $5 and a very big bar.

My bad that I made reservations at the wrong Sarabeth's (intended Central Park South, but reserved at Park Ave South); everything else was bad on their part. First (or actually, worst) was service. Not sure if the waiter was new, but given the fact that the restaurant was EMPTY, I was amazed how how inattentive he was. Luckily we were with a great group (of 8) or we would have been really upset at the incredibly long waits. Lowlights: 1) he offered bread, and evn after two prompts, only brought it AFTER dinner was served; 2) I had to get up and find him to interupt his conversation with another non-working waiter to ask for dessert menus.Food was medicro at best. While others enjoyed their dishes, my beet salad was pedestrian at best with bizarre goat cheese balls that were tasteless. The octopus was OK, but had many more pickle slides (?!) than octopus. I will say the ice cream sandwich flights were very good. Though even here, the cookies were not great and some of the ice cream seemed to have freezer burn.Overall, I would NOT recommend. Perhaps the other Sarabeths are better. I do appreciate the restaurant tolerating our mix-up in reservations and accepting us 15 minutes late, but given there was no one else there...
Warning: do not be impressed with the bakery in Chelsea Market and then visit this restaurant expecting the same quality.   Bland cafeteria food is what you'll get.  Ambience - same disappointment.

I came here while visiting New York City and had heard good things about Sarabeth's so came for brunch. I liked the European feel of the restaurant, a little upscale but not stuffy. The space was large and bright with a big wrap around bar at one end. The service was good but my omelet was not good. The muffin was decent but wish I would have gotten toast instead. My friend got the waffle of the day and she said it was good but not great. The best part of the meal were probably the cocktails. The prices were pretty expensive for the quality of the food so that's a bit disheartening. I probably wouldn't come back for their brunch but would be willing to come back for lunch or dinner to give that a shot.
Always good! Great for brunch. Lemon ricotta pancakes- to die for!!  Usually a wait unless you have reservations.

Great space, but not so great food! Terrible eggs benedict, the eggs looked like it was pre-made and the yolk was hard. The lemon ricotta pancakes were so dry, not lemony at all (Lacanda verde's blow them out of the waters). However, the seafood salad was filled with vet generous portions of lobster, crab etc. Not planning to visit again.

We went there for brunch and asked if we could be seated outside but after a while it got too cold and they were nice enough to change us to a table inside. I had the eggs benedict and the fat and fluffy french toast... the eggs were okay, nothing amazing, but the french toast was delicious! It was indeed fat and fluffy! My only complaint are the restrooms, not only do you have to go through hallways and hallways and stairs and more hallways but they are also sooooo dark! But besides that, food was pretty good as well as the service.

Service was great.  Food was delucious. I had the lemom ricotta pancakes. Yes you taste the lwmon, and the ricotta texture was evident. The syrup was light and just sweet enough. Mot wver sweet like store bought. The chicken apple sausage was cooked perfectly. I liked the grill marks that were present. The sausage was juicy, and the jam was a perfect offset.My daughter had a crabcake with salad and homemade chips. She didn't care for the chips, and said the salad was overwhelming. We had bottle flat water, which was continuously renewed and poured. It had a crisp and clean taste to it.The service was excellent. We were 15 minutes late of our reservation, but were accompanied with no problem. Everyone was professional and timely. Will return!!

I had an overpriced and disappointing brunch/lunch experience here.  I don't mind paying more for interesting, yummie food, but what we got was just "meh" and we left frustrated.I got the steak which was fine but lacking flavor. Same for the fries, boring. I've been to so many places in NYC where they do a really nice job with seasoning, and it's just not what we got here.My partner got the berry bowl. Heads up, its just berries, there's no honey or anything else to make it interesting. He also got the short rib hash. It tasted bland. He had to ask for hot sauce just to jazz it up a bit. We ordered the s'mores in a jar for dessert, this was so over-sweetened I almost sent it back.The only remarkable thing we ordered was the four flowers juiceAll in it was $120 for two people. Totally not worth it. The service was good, though.

Great and easy location to meet up with people. Food was ok but way overpriced for what it was. Cost for 4 people was 110$. Yikes we ordered eggs and pancakes basically and coffee. Too expensive in my opinion:( Many other breakfast places to choose from for sure:)

I came here for Saturday brunch with a couple of friends.  I suggest making a reservation because it will get crowded.  We were seated fairly promptly and our server was great throughout our stay.  She was knowledgeable about the menu and even made a few suggestions.The menu is your standard brunch fare with a twist.  I had the french toast with a side of bacon.  The french toast was fluffy and delicious and the bacon was perfectly crisp.  The portions were just right too.  I would definitely come back here.

The chicken blt type thing is good enough but kind of a tough sell for $20. The chicken was tender enough and I thought the bread was pretty solid. We were in a rush and they got our group in and out on time.
Their oyster is good! Come with 3 sauces. Tastes fresh and I didn't get food poisoning

Came in for brunch Saturday morning food took a bit long but the food was outstandingly delicious, our server Billy was great helping explain the menu and gave great service. Will be back again for sure the best brunch I've had !
Every time I'm in NY I must come to Sarabeth's Love their egg Benedict , jalapeño omelet , buttermilk pancakes and the four flowers drink

I'll start this review by saying I rarely write reviews for positive or negative experiences, but feel so strongly about my terrible experience at Sarabeth's this evening to write a review.  I took my family to Sarabeth's for Easter dinner this evening and was embarrassed at the complete lack of service.  We had to ask continually for things -- About an hour after checking in, we still hadn't received complete set of serviceware (I took plates and utensils off of other tables), I had to ask for bread baskets (which other tables had), my mother's soda beverage order (I was close to walking to the Walgreens around the corner to get her a can of soda).  The restaurant was not busy or full (it was 5.30pm after all) and had no idea why service was so lacking for my family dinner.  I even have video of how empty the restaurant was (which I would be happy to post).  To top if off, I was scolded by the restaurant manager in front of my family.  For a family dinner of 13, I had asked for the prix fix menu to be served (much easier for everyone).  In the three phone calls I had with the restaurant in the past week, this didn't appear to be a problem (so it wasn't a surprise).  Apparently it was a problem when I arrived at the restaurant.  The manager claimed that I hadn't returned their call this afternoon when in fact I did and had spoken to a man named Chris.  Again, the prix fix menu didn't seem to be a problem.  He begrudgingly made prix fix menus and dumped them with me -- I suppose expecting me to pass the menus to my family guests, but thankfully our waiter saw this and scooped them up to distribute to my family.  The manager also scolded me that I should have spoken to private dining to make arrangements.  Well guess what -- with the first phone call I made, the receptionist DID check with private dining and all was OK.  If it wasn't, I would have been happy to make arrangements directly with private dining -- all I needed was to be advised to do so.  I'll wrap up to say that at least Thankfully the food was good, but I'll NEVER come back again and would advise friends the same.  There are so many other choices in NYC -- I just selected the wrong place.  Thanks Sarabeth's for ruining my family Easter dinner.

For a place known for their muffins they get a thumbs down. The muffins we ordered came out cold and dry. At least warm them up a bit before serving. Waiter and staff seemed disinterested and board. Service was fair at best. Eggs were cold and bacon was burnt to a crisp. 3 orange juices were ordered for the kids that came out in wine glasses really??!! You wanted to serve juice to kids in wine glasses?? My French toast was below average. For the price this place was definitely not worth it. Will never go back here again.
Very expensive, otherwise completely forgetful.  The decor and staff are nice, but if you love good food, go someplace else.

Very mediocre and very overpriced. This place used to be the best in the city for brunch type of food. Now it's just overpriced and "good". Nothing special at all... sadly. Go to a good diner instead.

I've wanted to try Sarabeth's since passing the TriBeCa location on several occasions... The experience was "eh." Not so bad that I'd complain but so uninspiring that we won't be back. The front desk/hostess staff was friendly and attentive, as was the manager. Our server had little interest in the table and we saw the back of the house staff most frequently when they brought our food. The food... oh the food... Meatballs were a 4, and the highlight of our dinner. We also got the deviled eggs which were fine, and we'd get them again if there more people to help eat them, but not so tasty that two of us wanted to split five of them. We went light on entrees - I ordered the grilled cheese and tomato soup & E. the chicken salad. Both dishes were "left a lot to be desired." Someplace between a 2 & 3. The grilled cheese sat in the window too long and the chicken in his salad was so dry as to be nearly inedible. Finally, dessert was good... E enjoyed the truffle chocolate  cake. My raspberry bread pudding was okay. Perhaps it's because I expected a hearty, homey bread pudding and this was not that. This last item is why they received a 2: Walking back to the bathroom via a slight maze of halls and it smelled like urine. What's more, the fabric walls were stained and dirty. Had I gone to the bathroom prior to dinner we would have left. Perhaps someone braver than me would have the courage to share this with a manager in person, but I simply didn't. It feels like a lovely, welcoming beginning and then layers are peeled back to reveal an outdated and ill-kept experience.

I came in for breakfast. I ordered the Classic Eggs Benedicts ($20.50) It was okay. I have had better from other less expensive places. Overall, this place is overrated and very expensive for food that can be purchased at other places for cheaper. My friend got the Fat and Fluffy French Toast ($19), it was good but the center of the toast tasted a bit raw. Not coming here again because of its price and average taste in food.

Skirt steak with truffle fries - comfort food order but the steak was burned and the inside was cook medium well versus medium rare. Didn't finish the truffle fries.Dessert was very good.Do not recommend based solely on the skirt steak.

Best place to go for breakfast near Central Park! We didn't have to wait long on a Saturday. The service was quick, our waiter made sure that our coffee never got cold or cup got empty! I'll be dreaming of the French toast!

Very unimpressed with the sub-par yet expensive experience, especially considering the reputation of the brand. Came here for Sunday brunch. First off, their $14 "signature" Bloody Mary was terribly bland and watery and tasted like plain tomato juice. The lemon ricotta pancakes were undercooked and had doughy batter in the center. Finally I was really excited for the egg stuffed popovers, but they were terrible! The eggs were draped over two cold, tough, dry, vacuous, and totally flavorless popovers. It was kind of shocking. To make matters worse our waiter disappeared for 20 minutes while we were waiting for him to take our bill. The couple next to us had to complain to the maitre d'. Not worth your money.

Great food/wine and service at reasonable price. I like most things on their menu but my ultimate favourite is their lobster roll. Good for breakfast, lunch, or dinner, although I prefer lunch or dinner. Great with kids, small or semi-large groups, or if you're on your own.
Brunch menu is good, french toast and pancakes. Last time i went the french toast was undercooked and was still soggy from soaked egg water.. Rest is eh (omelettes, eggs benedict, etc).

Went here with my girlfriend for dinner last Wednesday night when they had a live band. The music was fantastic. The problem was with everything else - so much of a problem that I was inspired to write my first Yelp review!First of all, the food is wildly overpriced. For a burrata appetizer, a skirt steak, a burger, and one beer, the total came out to $90. You can do better at many of the great nearby restaurants. But the real problem was with management's approach to the place. My girlfriend ordered her burger medium, and it came out medium rare. No problem at all, as we assumed it would come back in two minutes a little bit better cooked (my meal had already arrived and we were trying to eat together). We waited a few minutes and didn't receive anything, so we start eating my meal. 10 minutes later, it's a completely new burger, and it's not better cooked, but actually fully rare this time. We explained the issue and asked for them to simply cook it more so that it could be medium. 10 more minutes and a THIRD new burger comes out, this time it's charred on the outside (crispy in fact) but still fully pink on the inside -- once again medium rare. She took a few bites and then left the rest of the burger sitting on the plate.Management came over to apologize but never took the burger off the bill. In fact, they still charged us $1.00 for the cheddar on the burger!Again, the music was great but do yourself a favor and eat at one of the many great places next door. Come to Sarabeth's before or afterwards for a drink.

Came here for brunch. The place is large but was still super crowded. Glad we had made a reservation on OpenTable. Didn't seat us until everyone in the party had arrived. Ordered the Goldie Lox, which was scrambled eggs with salmon and cream cheese. Yummy and came with a croissant. (You could also choose a muffin or toast.) The entrees are average priced at ~$18-$20, but the sides are expensive ($8-9 each). However the bacon was very good and worth the money. They refilled my iced coffee without charging me for another one. They also have soy milk. Overall, I'd say the menu isn't that unique, but the atmosphere is bright and lively, and they have all the classics you could want for brunch. Good experience. Service was friendly and attentive.

A perfect bright and airy place for brunch / lunch.  Lots of omelettes and benedicts  as well as salads to choose from.It's a tad bit pricey but the service is spot on and you never feel rushed.I've had the crab cake benedict and the 3 cheese omelette.  Both were very good.  The portions are huge so bring an appetite.

I visited Sarabeth's last summer, and I've only now gotten around to writing my review. Overall, this place wasn't anything to write home (or write on Yelp) about. While the atmosphere was lovely and the experience was quintessential brunch, I'd say that the food was only so-so, and not really worth the price. I don't think I'll be returning to Sarabeth's but I had a pretty good experience overall. Next time, I'll probably opt for one of the many other establishments in the area instead.

Very disappointed ordered my burger medium and it was well-down. Honestly this place is nothing but a HYPE. It's over priced the dishes are not worth what they cost. The food is not delicious or good. It seems rushed not fresh like it was made 30 minutes ago and they decided to wait 30 minutes for it to get old and Serve  it to you. I came here to visit from DC I would never come back. I would not bring my family here to eat. Total disappointment.

I picked up a MealPal at Sarabeth's and wanted to eat it quickly at one of many open tables, or open bar seats because it was 30 degrees outside but was refused. I asked for this to be run by the manager, and the woman who came back told me that there policy was not to let MealPal consumers eat in the restaurant. I've never been prevented from eating food purchased in a restaurant, at a restaurant. Way to show how you feel about the customer.

As soon as we got here I got a bad vibe from this place. The restaurant was empty and the hostess wanted to seat us at a tiny table next to the wall.. Whatever that's fine we asked to be moved and she complied. The service was good but the food was horrible. I ordered the truffle risotto and it tasted like dirty soil. My bf had a burger but it was over cooked. Another thing that bothered us was when we went to the restroom the entire hallway smelled like sewage. My bf assumed they were cleaning their grease traps which is fine but that should not be done during dining hours. Overall, would not recommend.

I'm usually a big fan of SB's so it hurts to write this.  However, had lunch there today and had the Jumbo Lump Crab Cake Sandwich described below.  It was very tasty.  But it was not a sandwich as it did not come on a roll.  And it was about the size of 4 cocktail sized crab cakes.  For $25, seriously?  Way overpriced.  I would have communicated this directly to them but did not see a feedback option on their website.JUMBO LUMP CRAB CAKE SANDWICHfrisée salad, housemade potato chips 25

Pros:The staff is very courteous and professional, and the barkeep was great as well. The drinks were delicious all around.Cons:I ordered the steak, and I gotta tell you... it was a bit over done. Now, I did order it well done (that's how I like it!) but you can still do a steak justice when you have it well done. They burned it quite a bit, and the fries tasted... off.It's a shame! I really wanted to like it. I'd give it another try.
Service is just OK, not on par with usual service I expect. Our server was rowdy - no sense of being a gentleman while doing the slightest things (I.e. Pouring water and coffee).
First time dining at Sarabeth's and it was great! Both the service and food were fantastic. We split the avocado toast as an appetizer and then I got the kale and eggs. It was hearty and delicious!

Went once will never go back.  I went into Sarabeths around noon for brunch today 1-21-2017.  Wait was very short (10 minutes) which was great however they tried to sit us (table for 2) at a long table that sits 6 with 4 strangers that were already occupying the other seats at the table.  When we asked to have our own table for two the put us in the bar area which we were ok with.  However no one came to even get us water or coffee for 17 minutes, even after we kept looking around to flag someone down to help us. When they finally came by the coffee they poured us was cold and they spilled it since they were running around.  I felt like I was in a highway diner. We eventually got our order in.  I ordered eggs Benedict and it was awful, might as well been pre heated.  The eggs and ham were a tiny portion and had no taste to them and the muffin it was on was hard like cardboard.  The table we were at was so small and the plates so big there was no room for our water or coffee mugs.Once biting into the muffin I immediately looked for a waiter. By the time I got someone it was ten minutes so instead of getting a new meal I just got the check.Most overrated over priced place I have ever been.  For two tiny portioned breakfast entrees, one side of potatoes and two decaf coffees it cost my $72.  Don't waste your money here.  Go up to Hendricks on 37 and third.  Eggs Benedict is $12 opposed to $19 and is delicious.Don't waste your time and money for brunch here.

This Sarabeth's is a cut above the others. It is more upscale and the service is great. The few times I have been here, it has been great.We had:- Branzino - very good- Grilled Chicken Salad - tasty- Scrambled Egg  Stuffed Popover - delicious, filled with cream cheese and scallions. A must have.- Gruyere Cheese Omelette - deliciousThey get you in and out in under and hour and the food is good. What more could you want?

For some reason got charged 6 bucks for 2 bottles of water, even thought I'm pretty sure it was just tap water (not even a sealed bottle, one of those reusable glass ones). Not to mention the waiter just brought us a full one at the end of our meal and apparently charged us for it even though we didn't ask for it.  I know one shouldn't not  nit-pick little things like this at a "fancy" restaurant but it left a bad taste in my mouth. Eggs Benedict were OK but not worth the price, there are better brunch places in NYC.

It's been 15 years since I was at a Sarabeth's.  I remembered a warm , homey restaurant with yummy breads and a roaring fire.  I went Sunday for brunch and was completely disappointed.  The restaurant was loud, with an overall cold feel.  The food arrived cold and absolutely nothing was brought to table.  We waited 20 minutes for a sandwich and eggs.  They ran out of muffins and scones. The had an English muffin left and brought that. It was Doughy and tasteless.  The final bill was $49.  I will never return.  Not a way to spend money and dine.

Very very disappointing. I've heard good things about this place and decided to give it a try twice (for meal pal). Portions were undesirably small and the dishes were lacking spices and anything tasty. Grilled chicken salad tasted like it was boiled in water thrown on top of some watercress. Very Meh indeed.

For a place that is famous for brunch, it was disappointing.  I had the egg w kale salad which was so boring and uninspired.  The sausage and veggie frittata was dry and tasteless.  The pastries were slightly dry and on the stale side.  The waiter was pleasant but did not listen well or answer questions properly.  There is better - skip this place

If you're going to go to Sarabeth's, go to their location on Central Park South. The parkside location has a much better ambiance than this location on Park Avenue, which really felt to me like a glorified diner offering what my breakfast buddy and I both felt was assembly-line service. My omelet (and the accompanying bread) was just OK - not bad, but nothing remarkable or worthy of a return visit. While the restaurant's layout lends itself to accommodating large parties, there are better options in Gramercy/Flatiron for those of you starting your day with just a couple of friends.
"The burrata on the avocado toast is god's cum dumpster" overheard from My friend as she took a bite

Their "English muffins" are thick heavy bread cut in half. Very disappointed in the quality and texture. Wish they would have told me before I ordered this monstrosity.  Burger was dry. Overpriced diner....

This is a perfectly decent restaurant. Absolutely nothing is outstanding EXCEPT their chocolate cake! We got appetizers (expensive and just avg), pizza (undercooked) and the scallops (good). It is a huge restaurant so if you have a large group, it's a good location. I hope this review doesn't comes across as if I dislike this spot. It's perfectly fine and you wont be disappointed. But let's be honest - this is NYC and bar is set high for taste. Btw, did I mention I love their chocolate cake???

The waitress who was taking care of us, Otillia,  brought our check back because we didn't tip her the SUGGESTED amount ... which she didn't deserve. Food was good nonetheless. Won't be back here if I have to give tip when I don't want to. Girl bye.

Place has gone down hill. Took my coworker for her farewell happy hour. My coworker asked to have the table cleaned at the bar and after they cleaned it they gave the table to someone else. We had to tell the manager the problem with the service for them to realize. It was not like this before. When the top of the sangria pitcher fell off to the ground, they rinsed it and gave it back to us instead of washing it. They gave us guac and chips on the house but we're not apologetic. Won't come back again knowing there are multiple restaurants in the area with better service.

What can I say, not that many options in this neighborhood but this SB is nothing like the others -- terrible! Worst service I have ever seen bordering true incompetence. Very unusual for this city. Seriously: I hate this place!

Sad to write a poor review as I've visited other Sarabeths. But food was subpar and on top of that they didn't even give me what I ordered! They told me they would change it but by that time I'd have to wait even longer. No comps. Hope my next visit will be better.

If I could give it zero stars I would.  DO NOT COME HERE WITH A PARTY OF 3!  We have been waiting an hour for brunch and they refuse to put us at a table for 4 or merge two tables together.  The front staff is nasty and non apologetic.  They literally sat us at the only table for 3 in the place.  Came here for my wife's birthday and never again.  What a joke!  I will also be letting he concierge at our hotel nearby know about their service.

Really a 3.5 star if possible. Cons - overpriced for what it is. portions are not large. Pros - if you are not too hungry and want to overpay, this is perfect. Ok enough jokes, but their food quality was good. I enjoyed their coffee and the Benedict was tasty. It was quite bite size, but good. Overall, good for groups with a good ambiance.

The chicken sausage & kale frittata was delicious and perfectly paired with a muffin.The restaurant is very spacious.Our waiter, Javiar, was great. He gave great suggestions for what to order and drink.The maze to get to the bathroom was well lit and nicely decorated.The bathrooms were clean (although they ran out of paper towels to dry my hands).Everyone is very pleasant from the moment you walk in until the moment you leave. You will be greeted or thanked with a smile. It was a wonderful first visit.I'll be back.

Not good. After searching for a nice sit down breakfast place online, this restaurant had good reviews. I ordered a cheese omelette with a croissant, but, I received a luke warm Parmesan mozzarella pack of unmelted cheese omelette with rye toast. So far off base. Then the bill came and the server said that he added, without my authorization, three cheeses that each cost $1. This is unbelievable. The menu does not say that. They fixed the bill after I complained to the server. When I approached the two managers, then they gave an extra 10% discount. Really? So, is it normal to take advantage of your customers?

Great sit down restaurant when you need to seat a lot of people. This place is beyond spacious! Typical breakfast/brunch items, but from what everyone in my party said, it was all pretty good! I got the quinoa crusted ahi tuna salad. The chunks of tuna were perfect medium rare and the addition of the crispy texture on the outside was great. The salad adds chunks of oranges that makes the salad even more refreshing. The pancakes that my coworker got also looked amazing! Smelled great and were perfectly fluffy

Waaay over priced for what it is. Definitely would put $$$ instead of $$. The service was horrible. Although we were ready to order the server still hadn't visited our table to ask us if we wanted beverages.

Great service! Really like the almond-crusted french toast. The strawberry sauce was perfect, not overly sweet. Enjoyed the chicken apple sausage. The portion sizes are great for two people to share. The Four Flowers mimosa and latte also hit the spot. I'll be back.

$$$$...$18-21 for an omelet? Over priced for an ordinary tasting omelet that I could make better. There's nothing special about this restaurant EXCEPT for the tomato soup. It was one of the best tomato soups I've ever had and would love to go back but I wouldn't pay $13 for a bowl. Service was good

came here with husband for brunch today. ordered the bacon not crispy and it came out almost burnt. they forgot my croissant that came with the meal and when I got my short ribs to go they forgot to give me the poblano sauce. for $52 I expected better service and attention to detail. this place is overpriced.

I love that place. There are plenty of healthy options. Service is prompt and food tastes amazing. We ordered seafood Cobb salad and jumbo lump crab cake sandwich. Both were super-delicious! Will definitely come back.

I'm only giving the 1 star review because the service was the issue here. The food was okay. Our waiter wasn't helpful. He didn't even take our order until about 10 minutes sitting (I guess we were forgotten). The people around the place (including our waiter) kind of just stood around, which indicated that they were not busy. When we were ready to leave and asked for the check, that took a good 15 minutes to come. But while we waited for that, and this is the main reason for the terrible review, another waiter dropped a saucer of Ketchup on the floor, which splattered all over my shoes and all over my friend's pants. It destroyed both my white shoes and his light blue pants. The waiter merely picked up the saucer, leaving ketchup all over the floor and walked away without saying one word. He never came back. No one ever said anything to us. They literally had to walk over the Ketchup which means they obviously saw it. We asked for more table clothes to clean ourselves up. No concern. No accountability. No apology, which I think if there was one this review would have actually been a good review.
it's wasn't anything special at all.  not much different from local diner, except this place is busy!
Disappointed. Had better bunch pancakes and egg Benedict elsewhere. Not worth the price and reservation. Go elsewhere.

My boyfriend & I have been here a couple of Times for brunch. Sarabeth's has a great elegant decor with amazing fresh food.  No wonder they are always packed!!! Nonetheless they always have availability & are willing to accommodate with short wait Times!! The Brunch is amazing! my Fav is the lemon ricotta pancakes! They are a must have as well as their Tartare.

This was our one and only awful SB experience : the waiter had little interest in us - or getting our order right , was looking all over the shop as we gave him our order and needless to say it allarrived wrong (he then blamed the kitchen ) ; the manageress came to apologize but was clearly just going through the motions with her pre prepared speech. (Other SB branches are excellent - have a great professional vibe - this was very different )
steak and frites are to die for. nice place, pricey, but the food and environment justify it.

I originally would have given them 3 stars, but I just received a notification that they canceled my OpentTable reservation after the fact, even though I came to the reservation on time and ate there. 1 star reduction for poor customer service.The food here is not great- just OK.Came for coworker's birthday lunch. Ordered Cobb Salad, Lobster Roll, and special Pizza with white truffle and asparagus. The pizza was just OK- didn't love the crust, it was a bit on the soggy side. The lobster roll was decent but also didn't compare to some other ones I've tried (I'm looking at you, Lobster & Burger). Chips that came with the lobster roll were soggy and not very flavorful- the coleslaw was also average at best. My friends seemed to enjoy the Cobb Salad, but it did not look especially appetizing to me. Cheesecake dessert was average. In my opinion, it's not worth for the price to go here. The food is just OK and seems the place is overpriced. Don't expect to get any points for OpenTable reservation since they will just cancel it.

We sat at the bar for happy hour and it was great!! The staff was super friendly and the atmosphere very chill! The happy hour food is a deal and perfect for an early dinner. We got a bunch of stuff: - the flat bread margarita pizza and it was just delicious. That said, it's hard to miss a bread/tomato/cheese/basil pie, but when it's good, it's good! - 6 oysters for $1 each and they were as crisp and fresh as it was called for this hot summer day! - beef sliders: the meat was great! Very juicy and perfectly cooked. I loved them. - the short ribs tater tots. Now that is where the place lost a star. The tater tots were very disappointing and were not tater tots. They were mashed potatoes mixed in with left over short ribs, made into a ball, dumped into breading and fried. It was NOT tater tots, it was deep fried flavored mashed potatoes. Also, it wasn't very good. I would love to go back and give a try to the rest of the menu. The space is gigantic, and if you go to the bathroom, you'll end up walking about half a block within the building!

Came here to have a quick birthday brunch with my best friend from college. The peach Bellini was amazing! Very strong and delicious. The service and decor was also wonderful. My water glass never emptied and our server was a perfect balance of attentive without being annoying. However, I had the farmers omelette (I think it's called that)-that is why it's 3 stars only. It was not very tasty, and was just OK. I expected more from a restaurant that charges $18 an omelette! It came with a choice of different bread items--I selected the croissant. That was delicious. Maybe if I came back and tried something else, I might enjoy the food more.

My boyfriend and I frequent Sarabeth's often. He usually gets the fat and fluffy french toast and I get the lemon ricotta pancakes with homefries on the side. The food never disappoints and every waiter we've had is so nice and attentive. Although the place has a bit of a diner feel, the prices are more expensive, but you're getting what you pay for with the great service and quality of food. We will continue to come here as long as we live in midtown.

Went here for lunch today and given the convenience of it's location, I was pretty satisfied. The ambiance is nice but pretty typical for a high(er) end spot in NYC. We started with the Crab Meat Guacamole and Chips, which were phenomenal but make sure you dig down to get a good bite with both the crab and guac - it's a great combination! For my entree, I really wanted the Grilled Fish Tacos but after I found out that the tortilla's were flour and not corn (WTF? no love for the gluten-less), I opted for the Roasted Chicken Salad. The dressing was light, but the greens were super fresh and the combination of grapes, marcona almonds and olives was delightful. I would only go back if I were taking a client out since it's kinda pricey for what you get.

My wife and I walked in to Sarabeth's at 1:35 PM today. The place was pretty quiet, almost kind of dead. At 1:50 PM, my wife and I left and ate at Dos Caminos just down the street. Why?Because between 1:35 and 1:50, no one came over to take our order. Given the price tags you put on your food, you should probably work on improving your service.

Was not impressed with Sarabeths for a Sunday brunchFarmers omelet which include gruyere, ham, and leeks-- were low quality ingredients. Leeks were chopped so finely you couldn't taste them and the ham was the cheap diced ham pieces. The muffins were dry and low quality. Coffee was burnt. Overpriced for low quality

Sadly disappointed at a recent dinner in both food and service.  This is the second  experience like this at Sarabeth's, and my last, as I will stick to their baked goods and coffee and tea, which are great.  Guests at the table were not served their meals at the same time.  One order was misplaced.  The wait staff came out to apologize about mistakes in the kitchen.  They were super nice about it, but it definitely throws off the occasion.  Mistakes happen for sure, but this is the second time.  After a long wait, when the food arrived, it was ordinary.  Yet, expensive.  The service was friendly and courteous, but not on point.  I enjoy Sarabeth's.  Just not for dinner.

I took my 6 year old son to NY for his first time a couple of weekends ago, and he is a pancake aficionado. :)  We sat in the patio area, and he ordered his pancakes, which were super fluffy, and delicious.  I had the short rib hash, and couldn't have been happier with it.  There was so much flavor, and I loved the green salsa served with it.  The muffin and preserve was great too, only wish I had room to eat everything.  Next time I'm in NY, I'll be sure to visit Sarabeth's.

I came here for lunch this afternoon. I told the hostess I was in a bit of a rush. She seated me and told me the server would be with me shortly. I waited 15 minutes. A couple of minutes before I got up to leave, the hostess seated a couple of young men and watched as the server rushed towards them to take their order. When I told the manager about this as I left, she apologized and offered to take my order. If I was in her place, I would have offered to a guest who was sitting and waiting for 15 minutes to come back at her convenience and eat as their guest. But then obviously, this is a place with limited courtesies.

VERY pricey. Sarabeth's is sophisticated. It's elegant. You really feel like you are getting a high-end brunch here. The peaceful ambiance seemed quite suitable for business meetings. The service was good and not too over-the-top. We were seated and served very quickly. The food is amazing. Everything on the menu looks delicious. I ordered the waffles and my cousin ordered the eggs Benedict. Both plates came out looking very nicely put together. My waffles were light and fluffy and the butter they put on it was very good. While I did not try my cousin's food she insists that "the eggs are perfectly cooked" and that "the bread is pretty good too". In short: the food is amazing but the bill made me cringe.

Ambience : This is a nice place.  Elegant, but not overly fancy.  High ceilings and great natural lighting.  Also pretty large actually.  This is not a place to come if you anticipate getting loud though.  The noise travels VERY easily.  The crowd also seems to be pretty business oriented.Service : Oh, what wonderful service though.  All of the servers and food/drink runners were so so sweet.  While I would've understood if they did tell my table to quiet down, they never gave us any trouble.  Food and drinks came out in adequate timing.Food and Drink :  Tbh,  I didn't really eat much from here.  The party I was with seemed to enjoy the food for the most part.  I only tried the (and I'm not sure of what they were called on the menu) fried goat cheese sticks and a berry sangria.  Not a fan of goat cheese, so that was a slightly unpleasant surprise, but if you like goat cheese then it's probably perfect as a starter.  I loved the sangria.  Very very sweet, and light on the wine taste.  The pitcher served served maybe 8?  I will say though that others weren't huge fans of it because it was so sweet.  Some declined, commented that it tasted like juice, or threw some of their left over red wine in.  So, if you like your drinks on the sweet side, I definitely recommend it.I'd like to try this place again, but under a different context.  Perhaps date night is  better suited..
Good lunch place if you want breakfast. Goldie lox omelette + sourdough toast at $17.50. A bit pricey but has a nice atmosphere to it.

Had dinner at this location with a large group.  The food was up to typical Sarabeth standards, including appetizers, entrees and desserts.  The service was quick and efficient but they did seem to rush us to order initially even though the restaurant was pretty empty.  Overall a very good experience.  The half priced bottles of wine were a pleasant surprise.

This place was recommended by our daughter's college roommate as one of the best for brunch in NYC, but frankly, we were less than impressed with it. We arrived on a Sunday at 12:20 for our 12:30 reservation, and did not get seated until almost 1. Sadly, the three of us were then given a four-person table situated right up against a column, so in fact, only three could actually ever sit there. Also, the table was in a strange area, between two separate dining rooms. As for the service, we hardly saw our waiter, and spent much of the time looking around for him in order to get coffee and water refills. My husband ordered the Apple Cinnamon French Toast and my daughter got the Goldilox, while I decided to try the Toasted Coconut Waffle with Pineapple, Mango and Maple Rum Butter. Our entrées were all OK, but nothing that special to justify the prices. We also added a side order of the Smoked Bacon about ten minutes into our meals, but asked to cancel it after 30 minutes because we were basically finished with everything. However, magically, the Bacon suddenly came out, and it was absolutely burnt to a crisp (and generally, I happen to like my bacon well done, though not charred). Anyway,  by this point, we were so disgusted with the whole situation, that we just wanted to Pay the check and leave . Yet, I will never understand  why it took so long to get the bacon,  and more importantly,  why they would serve something  so bad. Personally, I think  our waiter simply forgot to turn in the add-on (at least until we started asking him about it ). Really wish I had spoken up and sent it back, instead of paying the $9 and not eating much of it. With regard to decor, the restaurant is upscale and chic, though it does not feel stuffy. Diners were wearing everything from blue jeans to Business casual, and the noise level was a bit much. The three of us had to talk extremely loud, in order to be heard. All in all, despite the fact that we will probably never return here, I am still glad we tried Sarabeth and do think their menu is pretty extensive.

Food is good (probably a little over-hyped, but solid).  Service is good.  Biggest room for improvement - they need to do a deep cleaning of the restaurant.  The floor and tiles look worn and not clean and the place has a musty smell.  It's even worse if you have to go back through the maze to the restroom.  Would recommend they clean the restaurant - that would be worth another star IMO.

This is a very good place to meet friends, or to bring visitors to. Clean, great decorated place with excellent service, took a star for the limited selection and another for being little bit too pricy for the food/portions they serve.

I had an omelette with chicken sausage and Kale and avocado frittata which is delicious. Also, my friend told me this restaurant is famous because of the movie sex and the city. However, the price is kinda high for brunch. Overall good experience.
Eat at the bar. Super friendly staff and always a knockout breakfast. Omelettes and their yogurt bowl is always a hit, and their muffins are never disappointing.

Best happy hour at a quality establishment! Of course there are good happy hours at little dive places, but Sarabeth's offered a classy, fresh and professional ambiance with live music. Good was tasty and the price was more than reasonable for what you get, especially in that location.

one of my favorite brunch spots in the city, so this review is based only on Sunday brunches. if you plan on going its imperative to get a reservation so you can avoid a super long wait. once your entire party arrives they seat you promptly, rarely do restaurants run so on time with their reservations like they do. firstly the atmosphere is nice, very large space with a good amount of Windows to let in natural light. the service is fast and the wait staff is always very kind and helpful.  in terms of variety in the menu, they have a lot of omelettes and egg based foods (i mean IT IS brunch) but you can also get something like a burger, a salad, or even chicken n waffles. their menu is online for reference (always helpful)I'd reccomend spending a little more and getting bottomless mimosas for $25 (they really add up) if you plan on having a fun brunch. i am not a muffin girl but their muffin and preserves sampler is amazing. I'd say for a new York city brunch this place is priced pretty average but you get high quality service and good food in a nice atmosphere

Great place to bring family or friends for brunch. Came in on a weekday so it wasn't terribly busy. The service was great and the food was delicious. I loved that my water was always kept full and the waiter was constantly checking on how the food turned out. Will definitely come back. I would suggest making a reservation if you have a large party or come in on the weekends.
Went here for brunch/lunch. Everything was great, even the English muffins were homemade. I would definitely recommend even though the mimosas are unfortunately no longer bottomless

Not impressed whatsoever with this brunch spot. Overpriced and nothing amazing. I ordered the vegetable omelette and my boyfriend ordered the rib eye. the omelette was just okay and does not measure up to other options for brunch in NYC. We were seated in the back of the restaurant where all of the staff was eating. It was very distracting and overall very unimpressed with this brunch spot.

Had Avocado toast on MealPass two days in a row. Sarabeth's is much better than Wayside's. But for some reason my pickup box emanated a very unpleasant smell. When I was on my way back to the office I kept looking around to see who was stinking, but after I sat down at my desk and unwrapped the box I realized it was literally from my food. But it's only a smell, as I couldn't taste it. Overall nice toasts, but I'd much prefer Balthazar multigrain. It's also annoying that they make all the MealPass orders at once, so if you have a late pickup time your food will be cold, and cold sunny side up eggs are no good. The avocado paste combined with water from the burrata also soaked the bread underneath.
This restaurant deserves 5 stars. Service is great and so is the food. For a city restaurant the seating is spacious. Hope to go back soon.

Great brunch spot , but reservations are best.  Large bar and dining room help keep wait times to a minimum.  Food is typical Manhattan pricing, but high quality.  I'm also always able to get on street parking near this location.  Menu is not particularly inspired, but it's fine for hearty, traditional breakfast.

Although the ambiance is there, the food was not what I expected. Ordered an egg white vegetable omelette and it was not very good.. Friends ordered waffles and tuna salad, both good but nothing special. The three fruit fruit juice was the best, all fresh squeezed and cold. Definitely a cute brunch spot for pictures but foodies, the food is alright at best.

Not sure why this place was so hyped up. It was decent, and the location had a nice crowd that wasn't too loud, but personally Blue Dogs or even the Smiths were comparable if not more enjoyable in my opinion. It was probably too hyped up for me. Had the crab cake Benedict-- which I don't necessarily recommend. Great English muffins, so maybe the Goldie Lox with a side of the muffins? Or suck it up and wait at Blue Dogs.

I went to Sarabeth's for brunch on a Sunday. It had been a couple of years since I had been Sarabeth's and I had never been to this location. It was super crowded. We did have a reservation. I know it was Sunday brunch but even with a reservation we waited over a half hour  to get a table. The food was not as good as I remembered. I had the $18 Apple Cinnamon French Toast. It was good but nothing special and definitely not worth $18. It is pretty hard to mess up french toast. The location is very beautiful and spacious. I can't recommend it though. I won't be returning any time soon.

( I now see I checked in to the wrong location) Brunch in NYC is serious business. I don't mean getting dressed up, I mean people "brunch" as a term on the weekends and it's important to have a place to go and have good eats waiting at the other end. With that being said, when we head into town we do have some favorite spots to hang with my cousin. But we are always open to try a new brunch location, especially if the word on the street is good food or coffee....or dare I say alcohol. So my cousin said she had recently brunched at Sarabeth's and thought we'd like it, being our last day in the city we wanted good food and a casual vibe.We did make sure to get an earlier start than most New Yorker's probably do on a Saturday morning since we did have an early afternoon flight home. And Sarabeth's was open earlier than some other spots on a weekend. We showed up at 10 am on Saturday and there were plenty of open tables in this fairly large restaurant located Park and 28th. Service was great, we were served drinks and food very quickly at this earlier time. I ordered scrambled eggs in a popover with arugula on the side. I think they used 4-5 eggs so have a big appetite! But who doesn't love a popover!!! Simple and delicious and I always love a eggs on toast kind of breakfast, so I did enjoy this variation. This place opens early and is walking distance from where we stay so it gets the extra star.

A little cautious based on Yelp reviews, but we were very pleased with our brunch items.  Almond French toast very plentiful, strawberry sauce just perfect tartness/sweetness.  Frittata with kale and chicken sausage cooked perfectly and very nice sauce.  Other companion had omelette with no complaints. Side of potatoes was ample and served hot.  $14 bloody marry oversized with great pickled vegetable strips. Excellent service.  Quick but not hurried.  A little pricey but would come back.

After visiting other locations in Manhattan, exploring this Park Avenue South location was our first, but now checked off venue for my wife's all-time Sunday brunch list. First and foremost I praise any restaurant that's kid friendly, has room for strollers, provides plastic cups/straws, has patient waiters, and has a kids menu. They definitely earn a plus there. We promised our 2 toddlers pancakes so I couldnt let them down. Service was exceptional, eggs benedict and short rib hash were delicious (but expensive at $21 each), kids enjoyed the pancakes. Its not always easy to appreciate your meal with 2 toddlers then pay a lot for our dining experience compared to other restaurants in the area, but that was our choice and eventually I'll forget that I paid $8 for an OJ. I may return as a customer, but probably without the kids. Oh, and getting to the bathroom downstairs felt like a maze but depends on where you're sitting.

Sarabeths at this location has gone noticeably downhill.  Have been here various times for lunch, brunch and dinner - generally just ok, but a great space and friendly service.  The saving grace for them has always been brunch, but it seems they can't do this right anymore either; given the high prices now, no way it is worth it.Specifically, on recent visit, the Benedict was served with completely hard boiled eggs, the kale salad was mediocre, the omelet was lukewarm and bland, and the muffins did not seem fresh.  Overall, completely ridiculous when paying ~$20 per brunch dish.No need to go back here.
Mimosas, egg white spinach and goat cheese omelette is all I needed to get my day started! Must continue me back for happy hour and dollar ousters

I've always heard good things about Sarabeth's brunch and although I found the food to be adequate, it was just A-OK for me. I think what hindered the experience for me slightly was the price of the entrees, a little bit more on the expensive side compared to other brunch places that offer similar plates.I started off with the Bloody Mary ($13). The amount they give you is huge. It was like an endless amount of Bloody Mary. The drink itself was good. I was just meh on the pickled garnishes on top. Too sweet for my liking. For my entrée, I got the scrambled eggs stuffed popover. Overall, it was good. The scrambled eggs were cooked nicely, full of that scallion flavor with bits of creamy soft cream cheese in between. The popover was a little dry and overcooked but it was adequate with the meal. The side salad was nice and refreshing with the eggs. I also tried some of my friend's ricotta and lemon pancakes and found the portion to be plentiful and the pancakes to be nice and fluffy with a nice hint of lemon. Overall, it was a good meal. Reservations are definitely necessary for this place. The pricing was just a tad higher than I would like pay for what they were offering.

I love trying new places and before going to NY, I made sure to do my research to have a nice brunch during my stay and after looking at many places I came to the decision to pick Sarabeth's for Sunday brunch (this past Valentine's day). The wait was not long, maybe 20 minutes and we were seated (my daughter and I) which I thought was very quick giving it was both Sunday and Valentine's day. I ordered the steak and truffle fries, the almond crusted french toast for my daughter, an orange juice for her and a mimosa for me and the total bill was $92 and some change including tip. I found it extremely over priced for the food we got. The food was good but not worth paying nearly $100 for brunch for two with just one alcoholic beverage. I am from Miami so it's not like I am not used to over priced meals, but I've had the same quality food and even better for almost half the price in some of the most popular and high rated brunch places here.Overall I'd say it was a good meal however for the price it was not worth it.

Sarabeth's is a great spot for New Yorkers or families staying in the area to go to brunch. Sarabeth's is not flashy by any means, but a beautiful classic restaurant scaled much higher than a place like Penelope's. The bloody mary's are enormous and a work of art. Although Sarabeth's has a bottomless brunch option, I wouldn't consider this the place to get your Sunday buzz on. There were lots of strollers, but not any kids running around. The menu options were pretty standard. I ordered the lemon ricotta filled pancakes which were pretty good. I would recommend this place for people 30+ who are seeking a brunch atmosphere that has great service, child friendly, standard menu options, no wait time and nothing over the top.

Service is awful. Went today and it was practically empty and there were still long periods of time where our server was missing, yet there were several managers and hosts/hostesses just standing there. The food is good but it took forever to come out. When we hadn't seen our waitress in 20 min and wanted to order something else as well as get our dirty plates cleared we actually complained to a manager who did absolutely nothing. After we complained (which we never do) she actually asked us is there anything I can get you guys and my husband said I'll take another drink and she never even brought the drink...

Came in for brunch on a Sunday and it was packed.  We only waited about 20 minutes or so for a table. We ordered a coffee at the bar while we waited which was luke warm at best.  The jalapeño cheese omelet was good but nothing out of the ordinary.  The service was good.  I would go back but it didn't live up to the hype.

Came in for brunch with a friend and got the classic egg benedict. It was good and the presentation was beautiful but it was nothing fancy. I did not like the dressing on the salad and couldn't even finish half of it. For just a benedict, it costed $19 plus tips and tax I ended up paying $26 and I did not think it was worth it. You can get a benedict elsewhere for half the price which would probably taste the same.

This place is a little overrated. This was my second brunch here. The 1st time we had the stuffed popover and it was quite good. The 2nd time we had the pancakes, stuffed popover and kale & eggs. The popover wasn't as good as the 1st time, it actually wasn't good at all. While the pancakes and kale & eggs were both good, they weren't anything to write home about. The price just didn't seem worth it for what we were getting.  I also had the four flowers mimosa. I didn't particularly like the taste. The flavors just didn't mix well for me. I have also ordered dinner here a few times through seamless. Again, while most items aren't bad, they're not great and just don't justify the prices. Overall overpriced and underwhelming.

Been here many times because the food is great. But lately, they've been messy and slow on the service. Today, had my friends reservation at 12, hostess didn't check us in correctly and we waited until 1220pm to be led to table (while a 1215 table was in before us also 2 people). Anyways, waiter took forever to come to our table to order. Still, nothing has come to our table (1253pm). Getting more disappointed by this place. Recommend - park avenue winter across the street. Same pricy but 5 star service.

Contrary to the negative reviews I read about long waits or bad service, I enjoyed almost everything. My friends and I ordered 3 dishes and an appetizer to share for brunch. This Flatiron location is really big and it was like a maze to get to the bathroom.Anyway, we got the chips with guac and crabmeat for the appetizer. Housemade chips are always a plus in my book, and generous portion of crabmeat was fresh!We also ordered the Seafood Cobb Salad, Buttermilk Pancakes, and Almond Crusted French Toast. The french toast was def my ultimate fave. It was just the right amount of buttery-goodness, and texture was crunchy from the almonds, but soft on the inside. I kinda just wished I asked for the strawberry jam on the side (since I'm not a fan of jam).Seafood Cobb Salad was a whole $30, but totally worth it when you see the amount of lobster and crabmeat they give you. The only thing they were missing was dressing, but maybe they did that on purpose so we can taste the freshness of the sea...Buttermilk pancakes were actually meh. I mean you can't reallllyy go wrong with buttermilk pancakes, but next time I shall try the Lemon Ricotta pancakes.Overall: attentive and patient staff, good food, spacious area, but a lil steep on the prices, but when you share it, it's not too bad.

don't do it... just walk past and go to Hillstone across the street, Upland around the corner or even Dos Caminos a block down. the food was subpar and service was just.. blah .. appetizer came WITH the entree, one of my shrimps were NOT DE-VAINED - I would have eaten shrimp poop it I hadn't notice - and my wine glass had lip marks.to top it off, service didn't even care, she actually chuckled when I showed her shrimp poop on my dish 2 stars because the tomato soup was very good and the steak was cooked nicely.

I was excited to go here because of it's name and reputation. Lots of celebs seem to mention this place, so I wanted to give it a try. I'll have to admit we didn't come here for their breakfast or eat their jam...which is what Sarabeth's is famous for I guess? My friend and I came for dinner and she ordered pizza and I ordered the turkey burger. The place is just overly expensive for no reason - the food isn't anything special. I've had much taster food (farm fresh) for a fraction of the cost. You're really paying for the classy vibe in-doors. I wouldn't come back for dinner and don't really recommend it for date nights or to come with friends, etc for dinner. But I would give it 1 more chance for brunch...but I'm predicting it would still be disappointing.

I loved it from the minute I arrived. It's not too crowded, which was surprising, and it has nice tables and a bar area. I know this is a typical brunch place, but dinner was great.The service was very welcoming and the waitress was helpful and honest when asked for preferences. One thing I didn't like was that the bread on the table isn't fresh at all and it's not warm. But the food was good.I ordered the tomato soup and the crab cake and, honestly, I liked the tomato soup better. It was best tomato soup I've had and was a great size for an appetizer. On the other hand, the crab cake dish was pretty and tasty, but just didn't have the kick I wanted.I give this place four stars because of the atmosphere and the fantastic and enthusiastic service. I take away one because i had higher expectations for the crab cake. Granted Sarabeth's is known for brunch, so maybe I should come back for their specialty

Great burger was great in its preparation. The customer service equally great. Jarvis is a great waiter. However, my friend's chicken pot pie was clearly microwaved and the food just has none of that "x factor" that makes it special. For the price it may be worth the experience, though in no way a 'must eat at' location.
Omelette I got was good but my muffin was dry and flavorless. The food is ok, but not worth the high price.

In NYC with my parents,  we thought we would go to a "nice" restaurant for breakfast instead of the little neighborhood markets we frequent and love.  $100 for four people, definitely not worth it.  Four flowers juice was excellent.  Lemon ricotta pancakes were gummy and gross.   My husband  loves omelets but didn't  finish his because he didn't care for it, plus his muffin was cold.   COLD.   Stepmother's steel cut oatmeal was runny, father said his Yogurt was good as was the bacon.  What a disappointment!

For NYC this place is weak.  Although the restaurant space is beautiful and somewhat alluring, the food is uninspiring and not very good.  Had the short rib hash for breakfast - sunny side up eggs were so overcooked that the yolk was completely cooked through, huge disappointment.  Breakfast came with muffins and scones, which to our disappointment were not house made and flavored with artificial flavoring.

Would have loved to have given a 5 star.  But the service was horrible.  Server acted as if he were second class citizens.  He was extremely rude.  Never checked back with and then dropped our check off without even a thank you.

I have had brunch now at most of the locations and its always yummy. The popover dish with the eggs and cream cheese is amazing and my favorite go-to. You need a reservation and there is normally a wait. The location by the park is better I think simply because you can eat outside and be by the park. This location is huge though. Love their coffee as well! Cant go wrong - solid brunch spot with a full bar.

After all the hype and recommendations we decided to come here. The ridiculous pricing was expected and no surprise. There was no excuse however, for the inattentive nature of the service staff, the slow kitchen and the tables around us seated after us finishing before we ever receive our food.  The slow kitchen and lack listed service is NOT what I expected from such an establishment. And it's over priced for breakfast!!!

My family and I were staying at a near by hotel, so we asked our door man where we could get breakfast and he suggested Sarabeths. When we arrived they were still offering brunch for it was a Sunday. I ordered the jalapeño omelette with a croissant. I was not impressed at all! The eggs needed flavor or at least a little salt! I must say for what we paid it really wasn't worth it!

Honestly, I'd give it 3 stars for the breakfast food and zero for service. I eat breakfast here about once a month. It's never full and good for groups, tables are comparatively large for most NYC breakfast/brunch experiences. The food is a bit over priced but dependable. The SERVICE is the WORST. Worst as in I have gotten up to go to the bar to get my own coffee and water, not during a slammed brunch hour, during an empty weekday breakfast shift while I watched 3 different waiters giggle and check their phones together in the corner. When they do decide show up at your table they are dismissive and rude. I can only speak for the before noon shift, but it is regularly the same staff and same experience. To be fair, the management is lovely. Every time I have brought my experience to their attention they have been more than accommodating. Wish that spirit would overflow into the waitstaff.

After coming to this location, I've determined that Sarabeth's is better a) at Central Park South or TriBeCa and b) for brunch. My dinner here was fine, but definitely nothing special. The space is huge! Like, I nearly got lost on the way to the bathroom huge. And for an earlyish dinner on a Friday, there were tons of available seats when we arrived without a reservation. Highlights of the meal include the house Riesling and the crab avocado guacamole (very fresh). Our entrees, a special flatbread and wild mushroom risotto, were on the richer side but not very compelling otherwise. Lowlights include pretty slow service when trying to get the check and feeling underwhelmed enough to forgo ordering any more food or dessert. For the price and hype, I'd head up or downtown if Sarabeth's is a must-try on your list.

DO NOT EAT HERE IF YOU HAVE A FOOD ALLERGY.  I recently visited the Park Avenue South location for Thanksgiving dinner.  When the reservation was made, we informed the restaurant that I have a food allergy and asked if they would be able to accommodate that with their fixed holiday menu.  We were informed that it was no problem to accommodate my allergy.  When we arrived for dinner, the waiter informed me that they would only serve me 2 out of 4 courses due to my allergy, which should have been explained when we inquired about this.  I certainly do not think serving someone half the courses qualifies as accommodating an allergy without a problem.  I explained to the waiter that if I was only going to be served half of the courses, the restaurant would need to adjust our bill, as we should not be billed the full price when they were not serving me a full meal.  At this point, the manager visited our table and said that they would be able to provide me with four courses, assuring me that all of them would accommodate my allergy.  When dessert arrived at the end of the meal, I suspected that it may contain the allergen.  I asked the waiter and he was unsure (which is unacceptable), so I then asked to speak to the manager, who was also unsure as to the ingredients (even more unacceptable).  I informed the restaurant of my food allergy when making the reservation, reminded them again when I arrived, and spoke with the waiter and manager who assured me it would not be a problem, yet they served me food that may have contained the allergen anyway.  Not only did they do this, but I was offered no sort of apology or replacement; I was simply instructed to not eat it.  If you have any type of food allergy, do not eat here.  They obviously do not take this seriously and it could result in a very dangerous/life threatening situation for someone.  I should also mention that I e-mailed the restaurant after this experience and have yet to receive any type of response, again leading me to believe that this is not an important issue to them.  Beware.

I was excited to go to the well known Sarabeths today and it definitely lives up to its name and reputation. Although somewhat on the expensive side for what it is, everything my friends and I ordered from the brunch/ lunch menu was fresh and delicious. Whether it was one of the egg dishes, a lunch or entree, everything was well seasoned, cooked and prepared. Service is great and friendly. The booths are also super comfy. Decor is classy.
Great breakfast. Refined dishes good setting. I had the eggs Benedict w/salmon. My girlfriend had an omelet which was perfectly cooked.
Very nice place for brunch! They were very busy, but our waitress was so professional, kind, sweet and honest) Food is delicious! Will come back for dinner!

Ate here at the invitation of a friend who is a very big player on Wall Street. I guess lots of deal makers take people to this restaurant because the restaurant is very business-friendly and have private dining nooks for making deals. The person who took me here is not the type of person who would go anywhere that is not first-class.I was a bit surprised by the menu. It didn't seem like the typical Scotch and Steak place favored by most of the Wall Street crowd. It almost felt corporate and kind of sterile. But safe. However, the food was pretty good and I guess you could call the menu pretty safe as well because there was something for everyone.I had the steak, which was done well and seasoned nicely. The Walforff salad was good as well. I wouldn't call anything I ate the best I'd ever have but it was all pretty good and did the job. The prices were pretty much on par with NYC ... higher than you'd expect anywhere else. I understand that they are known for their brunch ... which would make sense to me because it has that 'American-French Bistro' vibe. Seems like the type of place 'the girls' would like for brunch.This is probably not a spot I would pick for an amazing meal if I was in the city and dining for the experience. But for doing business ... it has a pretty safe menu, is spotless/clean and generic-enough where it won't take the attention away from the deal. The wait staff is very good about getting you what you need for the meal but disappearing while the business talk takes place. It is clear that this is a place people use when they are having business lunches and maybe not so concerned about the actual food or an innovative menu.Will come back and try brunch sometime when it's not a 'working lunch'. Pictures look good on here.

I was in NYC for the weekend, and came to Sarabeth's for brunch because it was one of my friend's favorite brunch spots. Overall, I walked out unimpressed and underwhelmed. When entering the location, I was immediately taken by how nice the place was and the ambiance of the restaurant. At 2:30pm, it was not difficult to be seated quickly. I also appreciated how quick the service was, and we received our food very soon after ordering. I split an adult grilled cheese and the buttermilk pancakes with someone. The portions were pretty small considering how expensive the items were. The adult grilled cheese was very small. While I thought it and the tomato soup accompanying it was good (but nothing special), it was definitely not worth the price. The pretzel bread was soft and chewy and I enjoyed that, but the cheese inside tasted pretty ordinary to me. The soup was creamy as promised, however much chunkier than I would have preferred. The buttermilk pancakes were also a bit of a letdown. Sure, the pancakes were good and fluffy, but again, nothing special. Considering they were $20, I thought they were sorely overpriced for what I got. I realize that it's hard to make buttermilk pancakes very unique, so at the least I expected there to be a lot of fresh strawberries. What I got instead were 6 small strawberry pieces that weren't even sweet/ripe! They were light red / white in spots and so I was immediately turned off by them. My friends ordered the jalapeno & cheddar omelet, and were also not too satisfied by it. They had to use salt / pepper because the omelet was bland and flavorless, which they did not expect since it is a jalapeno omelet. They only finally tasted the jalapeño flavor when they reached the center of the omelet. We had heard good things about the omelet, so maybe they were having an off-day, but that just means they lack consistency in their food. I had another friend order the unlimited cocktails package which was well-priced at $25.
